title.text: The MATE/GNOME Proposals for Anaphoric Annotation, Revisited

abstractContent.text: In the five years since it was proposed, the MATE scheme for anaphoric annotation has been used in a variety of annotation projects, and the resulting corpora have been used to study both anaphora resolution and NL generation.
Annotation tools inspired by the proposals have been used in some of these projects.
In this paper we discuss these first experiences with the scheme, some lessons that have been learned, and suggest a few modifications.

introductionContent.text: The MATE 'meta-scheme' for anaphora annotation) is one of the annotation schemes developed as part of the MATE project (), whose goal was to develop annotation tools suitable for different types of dialogue annotation.

The scheme has served as the basis fora number of annotation projects, such as the development of the GNOME corpus) and, more recently, of the VENEX corpus of anaphora in Italian spoken dialogue and text).

The GNOME corpus has been used to study salience, particularly as formalized in Centering theory (), to develop statistical models of natural language generation (e.g.,) and to evaluate anaphora resolution systems, with a special focus on the resolution of bridging references).
Aspects of the scheme have been implemented in annotation tools including MMAX and the Annotator tool developed by ILSP.
As a result of this work, many aspects of the proposals concerning anaphoric annotation made in and GNOME have been subjected to a thorough test.
In this paper we discuss some of the lessons learned through this work, some issues that have been raised, and how they have been or could be addressed.
